Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Galaxy Encounters on FIRE: Decoding Interaction-Induced Star Formation in the Local Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interacting galaxies are a major part of the history, evolution, and dynamics of galaxies. Projects are now beginning to measure the internal structure and motions in these fascinating systems, and so the time is right to carry out theoretical work capable of understanding these observations. This project will produce a comprehensive suite of galaxy merger simulations and turn them into simulated images and velocity maps to guide the interpretation of forthcoming data. The research connects a primarily undergraduate institution with cutting edge, world class theorists and observers, providing valuable experiences for under-represented college and high school students.

This research will employ state-of-the-art numerical simulations to investigate the internal structure and kinematics of interacting galaxies. For the first time, observations in the Local Universe are measuring these characteristics with exquisite detail, and for a large number of systems, using deep imaging and integral-field spectroscopy. The PI and collaborators will use the FIRE (Feedback In Realistic Environments) model to construct a comprehensive suite of galaxy merger simulations, resolving Giant Molecular Clouds and the Interstellar Medium, and directly implementing star-formation and feedback physics. Post-processing by radiative-transfer codes will create synthetic images resembling real galaxies, which will be classified both visually and with automated schemes. Along with kinematic maps, these will support planned observational projects. This three-pronged design of visual, automated and kinematic classification will help to overcome any obstacles. All theoretical tools have been fully tested, and undergraduate mentoring plans already exist using two postdocs and a graduate student. Considerable efforts are being made to recruit under-represented students from local state universities and community colleges, using two existing frameworks, and allowing them to work with a world-class team of theorists and observers. The project also involves high school teachers and students from the local under-served Hispanic community, aided by the PI's native language being Spanish.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes obtain thanks to funding from NSF Award #1822541 include:

  • A comprehensive suite (11 terabytes) of high-resolution galaxy merger simulations (Figure 1). Visit https://research.pomona.edu/galaxymergers/ for details.
  • A pipeline to track how different gas phases in the interstellar medium interact with one another and their role in fueling star formation.
  • Deep learning algorithms to identify merger-driven features.
  • A pipeline to identify and track the evolution of gas clumps.

This has yielded the following publications:

  1. Moreno J., et al. Interacting galaxies on FIRE-2: The connection between enhanced star formation and interstellar gas content, MNRAS, 485, 1320 (2019)
  2. Bottrell et al., Interacting galaxies on FIRE-2: Deep learning predictions of galaxy merger stage and the importance of observational realism, MNRAS, 4, 5390 (2019)
  3. Moreno J. et al. Mapping the interstellar medium and strr formation in interacting galaxies, MNRAS, submitted
  4. Patton et al., Interacting galaxies in the IllustrisTNG simulations - I: Enhanced star formation, MNRAS, in press
  5. Blumenthal K., Moreno J.. et al. Galaxy interactions in IllustrisTNG-100, I: The power and limitations of visual identification, MNRAS, 2, 2075 (2019)
  6. Shankar F. et al. Breaking degeneracies: Accretion histories, scaling relations, cluster- ing, and implications for the mean radiative efficiency of SMBHs, Nature, accepted
  7. Bluck A. F. L., et al., What shapes a galaxy? Unraveling the role of mass, environment and star formation in forming galactic structure with the SDSS, Illustris and L-Galaxies, MNRAS, 485, 666 (2019)
  8. Bluck A. F. L., et al., The impact of galactic properties and environment on the quench- ing of central and satellite galaxies: a comparison between SDSS, Illustris and L- Galaxies, MNRAS 462, 2559 (2016)
  9. Patton D. R., et al., Galaxy pairs in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey - XI. Measuring the influence of the closest companion out to wide separations, MNRAS 461, 2589 (2016)

The following papers are currently in preparation:

  1. Shah et al., AGN Enhancement in Interacting galaxies at 0.5 < z < 3.0, ApJ, in prep
  2. Blumenthal K., Barnes J., Moreno J., et al. Galaxy interactions in IllustrisTNG, II: Orbit characterisation and lessons for idealised simulations, MNRAS, in prep
  3. Weston M., Mantha K. B., Moreno J., et al. MergerPhot: A Multi-Wavelength Isophotal Aperture Photometry Code for Nearby Merging Galaxies, PASP, in prep
  4. Moreno J., et al. Interaction-induced stellar size evolution, MNRAS, in prep
  5. *Martinez-Pati?o L., Moreno J., et al. Interacting galaxies on FIRE-2: Galactic bridges and tails, MNRAS, in prep
  6. *Twum A., Moreno J., et al. Interacting galaxies on FIRE-2: Stellar shell dynamics, MNRAS, in prep

This list includes 13 women, 16 people of color, and 9 women of color, 6 Latinas or Black women.

 

 

 

*Students who participated in the Harvard Aztlan Institute (Figures 2 and 3), a summer reserach program for undergraduate students of color with a social justice component, funded primarily with this grant.

Lastly, this project served for multidisciplinary research work with an ethnomusicologist:

1. Vallejo J. & Moreno J., Intergalactic Pachamama: Kichwa Cosmology vs. Western Astrophysics, Smithsonian Folklife. Language & Traditional Knowledge (2018)

Overall, this grant supported 16 publications (6 in preparation), 19 undergraduate students, 2 graduate students, and resulted in 26 invited colloquia in the US, 6 invited colloquia abroad, 5 invited conference talks, 6 contributed conference talks, and 2 prized lectureships.
